thread.title: Arts and recreation tops growth sectors
thread.title_full: Arts and recreation tops growth sectors

title: Arts and recreation tops growth sectors
text:
Wed, Aug 5, 2015, 1:48 PM AEST - Australia Markets close in 2 hrs 12 mins Arts and recreation tops growth sectors AAP â€“ 1 hour 2 minutes ago Recommend Print 
Arts and recreation is Australia's strongest career sector when it comes to employment growth, according the inaugural Careers in Australia Report by comparison website finder.com.au. 
Analysis of 18 industry sectors revealed arts and recreational services had the highest employment growth rate over the past two years, of 20.6 per cent. 
This was followed by the agriculture, forestry and fishing industry and then electricity, gas, water, and waste services. 
Mining is considered the weakest industry, recording a 17.3 per cent drop in the past two years, followed by wholesale trade which dropped by 16.7 per cent, and information, media and telecommunications which recorded a slight drop of one per cent. 
Finder.com.au's Michelle Hutchison says the findings will help Australians make better informed career choices. 
"Understanding the employment landscape is important to almost every Australian. It can help you decide on which career path to take, if your industry is strong or if you should make a career change," she says. 
According to the findings, the five strongest industries are: 
1 - Arts and recreation services - growth rate of 20.59 per cent, employing 240,503 people in February 2015, compared to 199,602 in 2013 
2 - Agriculture, forestry and fishing - growth of 10.09 per cent, employing 325,321 in February 2015, compared to 295,495 in 2013 
3 - Electricity, gas, water and waste services - growth of 9.35 per cent, employing 148,106 in 2015, compared to 135,442 in 2013 
4 - Professional, scientific and technical services - growth of 8.48 per cent, employing 987,846 in 2015, compared to 910,622 in 2013 
5 -Accommodation and food services - growth of 7.5 per cent, employing 842,394 in 2015, compared to 783,613 in 2013. 
Casting the figures back to 1984, the highest growth category is professional, scientific and technical services, followed by arts and recreational services and administrative and support services. 
Based on the number of people employed, the top five industries as of February 2015 are: 
1 - Health care and social help - 1,460,281 
2 - Retail - 1,232,590 
4 - Professional, scientific and technical services - 987,846 
5 - Manufacturing - 922,447
